Fixing the "expected ; before" error in C++

C++ is strict about punctuation. If the compiler cannot find a semicolon where it expects one, it stops and emits an error like expected ‘;’ before ‘token’. This guide explains what the message really means, shows a failing snippet, and walks through a clean fix you can test immediately in the Local Online Compiler.

Why this error appears

  • You ended a statement without a semicolon.
  • You accidentally removed a closing brace, so the parser thinks the statement continues.
  • You added a stray colon or comma in a declaration.
// Broken: missing semicolon
int add(int a, int b) {
    return a + b
}

int main() {
    int total = add(2, 3);
    std::cout << total << std::endl;
}
// Fixed
int add(int a, int b) {
    return a + b;
}

int main() {
    int total = add(2, 3);
    std::cout << total << std::endl;
}

Quick checklist

  1. Scan the line the compiler reports and the line right before it.
  2. Ensure every return statement ends with ;.
  3. Check that braces are balanced so the parser is not reading into the next function.
  4. Rebuild and confirm the message is gone.
